ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Conceptual understanding and calculations for the transport of organic chemicals in the environment.
familiarity with environmental partitioning, basic environmental concepts like photochemistry, bioaccumulation, biodegradation, etc.
Partitioning in the environment and within organisms. How to deal with unknown values and estimation.
An introduction to the basics of organic pollutants and their transformation in aquatic systems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was challenging but doable and the professor is great, but the textbook was not very helpful.

strengths: large scope, excellent examples from instructor experience / research, weakness: textbook was a little difficult to follow and some homework problems had typos / were unclear Understanding could be improved if homework was divided into weekly chunks instead of multiweek giant packets. This way students would have more frequent feedback from TA / instructor about concepts they may be struggling with.
I think the only real weakness of the course was the book's lack of example problems. John did a great job explaining the theory and math behind problems.

The material is relevant to understanding how organic compounds effect and transform as they enter the environment. The amount and speed of material presented was fair. There should be more examples/applications of the equations presented so that students can understand how to use the equations for different situations. Also, I found the textbook that was used to be very hard to understand. It did not clarify anything that I learned in class, making it hard to strengthen my learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes as the professor is great and you will be able to model organic chemicals throughout different environments after taking the class.
Yes, the topic is very important.
Yes, I believe knowing partitioning is key to any environmental engineers work.

If the class improves in how the material is presented, I would recommend this course. With more practice problems in class gone over more thoroughly and a better textbook, I think this class will improve greatly.
